elements.title: Protection-First Information Hierarchy for Premium Hosts
elements.problem: The platform's information hierarchy leads with income potential (pricing, earnings projections). But Kris's primary information need is protection: how guests are vetted, what guarantees exist, how his art and property are safeguarded. Loss aversion research shows protection concerns carry 2x the emotional weight of income gains. The current hierarchy inverts the premium host's actual decision priority, forcing them to scroll past income data to find the protection information they need to feel safe.
elements.solution: Restructure the information hierarchy to lead with protection for premium hosts. (1) Evaluation page scan order: 'How we protect your property' banner > vetting process summary (credit check, references, guarantee) > guest quality stats ('94% of our guests are working professionals') > then income projection. (2) Active lease dashboard: Guest verification badge and protection status indicator appear in the top-left (first scan position), not hidden in a profile tab. (3) Use progressive disclosure: Protection summary always visible; detailed vetting report available on tap. Income details in a secondary tab. (4) Frame the payment guarantee as a protection feature, not an income feature: 'Your rent is protected' not 'Your income is guaranteed.'

evidence.quote: I've got some really good art in that apartment. So I want to make sure...
evidence.insight: Protection is Kris's primary information need. It surfaces unprompted, late in the call, as an anxiety that has been building throughout.

evidence.quote: The prospect of losing something makes you twice as miserable as the prospect of gaining the same thing makes you happy.
evidence.insight: Information hierarchy should mirror emotional hierarchy. Protection information (loss prevention) must appear before income information (gain) because it carries 2x the emotional weight.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: Property protection status and guest verification. Secondary: Earnings and income data. Tertiary: Marketplace activity and platform features. The emotional weight of loss prevention means protection must always be above the fold.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Always-visible: protection status badge + guest verification summary. On-tap: full vetting report, credit check details, insurance coverage. On-request: income projections, market comparisons.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Protection summary must be scannable in under 3 data points: (1) Guest verified status, (2) Payment guarantee active, (3) Insurance/protection level. Do not exceed 3 items in the primary protection display.
exclude: Detailed vetting methodology (belongs in a secondary view)
Legal terms of guarantee (link to full document)
Marketplace statistics that don't relate to this host's listing

elements.title: Anchored Pricing Display: Comps Before Inputs
elements.problem: Kris asks 'How much do you think I should rent this place for?' before seeing any market data. The platform's current pricing step presents a blank field, requiring the host to anchor on their own number (which may be their rent, a guess, or an Airbnb comparison). Thaler and Sunstein show that anchors — even arbitrary ones — profoundly shape decisions. The platform must provide the right anchor before asking for input, or hosts will anchor on wrong numbers.
elements.solution: Display comparable listing data before revealing the price input field. (1) Show 3-5 comparable listings in the host's area with their nightly rates, occupancy rates, and key features. (2) Highlight the recommended price as a large, prominent number above the input field — this becomes the anchor. (3) Show the host's cost basis ($5,500/mo) alongside the recommended nightly rate and calculate the implied ROI: 'At $X/night, your expected monthly income covers your rent and earns $Y extra.' (4) Frame the price relative to the host's rent, not relative to abstract market data. Kris thinks in terms of $5,500/mo — show him how the nightly rate maps to that frame.

evidence.quote: How much do you think I should rent this place for? Cause I pay about $5,500 a month... We kind of have a tool based on similar listings.
evidence.insight: Kris provides his anchor ($5,500/mo) and asks for a better one. Bryant promises a comp-based recommendation. The platform must deliver this before the price field appears.

evidence.quote: You start with some anchor, a number you know, and adjust in the direction you think is appropriate. The bias occurs because the adjustments are typically insufficient... Even obviously irrelevant anchors creep into the decision-making process.
evidence.insight: If the platform shows comps at $200/night before asking for input, hosts will anchor near $200. If it shows a blank field, hosts anchor on their rent or a random number. The order of information display is the nudge.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: Recommended price (large, prominent). Secondary: Comparable listings data that justifies the recommendation. Tertiary: Price input field for adjustment. The anchor must come before the input, never after.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Step 1: Show recommended price with headline ROI calculation. Step 2: Show 3-5 comps on tap for hosts who want validation. Step 3: Allow adjustment via slider from the recommended price, not a blank field.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 3 comparable listings shown by default. Price displayed in the host's mental model (monthly income relative to rent), not just nightly rate. No more than 2 numbers on screen at the recommendation step.
scan_order: Monthly income calculation relative to rent
exclude: Platform fee structure at the pricing step (show at checkout/confirmation)
Complex market analytics that require interpretation
Multiple pricing tiers or models at the first pass (progressive disclosure)

elements.title: Agent Continuity Display: Call-to-Platform Information Bridge
elements.problem: Information discussed on the phone call (property details, pricing expectations, schedule, concerns) does not persist into the platform experience. When Kris or Christiana logs in, the platform has no memory of what Bryant discussed. This creates an information gap: the host must re-enter or re-discover information that was already exchanged. The Nudge book emphasizes that choice architecture is inevitable — the platform's choice to show a blank dashboard instead of a call-informed dashboard is itself a choice that communicates 'we don't know you.'
elements.solution: Bridge call information to platform display. (1) After an agent call, the platform should show a 'Your agent noted' section at the top of the dashboard with key call outcomes: recommended price, schedule captured, photos needed, concerns logged. (2) Agent name and photo visible on the dashboard — the platform inherits trust from the person. (3) Call-derived data pre-populates relevant fields: schedule from call notes fills the availability calendar; pricing discussion fills the recommended rate; property details fill listing description. (4) If any information is missing, the platform asks for it in the context of the call: 'Bryant mentioned your apartment has a rooftop — would you like to add photos of the rooftop to your listing?'

evidence.quote: It's really a great fit because a lot of the people that we work with complement your schedule... That's great. So, you know, it's a nice apartment. It's on the nicest street in New York.
evidence.insight: Rich property context is exchanged verbally. The platform should display: 'Bryant confirmed your 3-week availability schedule is a great fit for our guest pool. Your property at 57th between Park & Lex has been noted as premium.'

evidence.quote: Choice architects can make major improvements to the lives of others by designing user-friendly environments. Many of the most successful companies have succeeded in the marketplace for exactly that reason.
evidence.insight: The information bridge IS the choice architecture. Showing call data on the platform turns a cold digital experience into a warm continuation of a human conversation.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: Agent-noted items requiring host action (e.g., 'Upload better photos'). Secondary: Pre-filled data from call for review (e.g., schedule, pricing). Tertiary: Standard platform onboarding content.
elements.disclosure_pattern: On first login after a call: Display agent summary card prominently. On subsequent logins: Move agent notes to a sidebar reference. Once all call-derived actions are complete: Collapse to agent contact info only.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Agent summary card: maximum 4 items. Each item: one sentence + one action button. No more than 2 actions requiring immediate attention.
exclude: Full call transcript (never show this to the host)
Internal agent notes not meant for host eyes
Platform features not discussed in the call

elements.title: Schedule-as-Value Framing: Availability as Income Opportunity
elements.problem: Kris describes his schedule as a personal routine ('I go away for three weeks, come back for two weeks'). He frames availability as absence, not as inventory. The platform must reframe this information: Kris's 3-week absences are not empty weeks — they are 21 bookable nights per month. The Nudge book's framing effect shows that how information is presented changes decisions. 'You're away 3 weeks' feels passive. '21 nights available per month at $X/night = $Y/month' feels actionable. The platform's information architecture must translate the host's personal frame into a value frame.
elements.solution: Display schedule information in a dual frame: personal context + income opportunity. (1) Calendar view: Show Kris's schedule with his language ('Away: Feb 21 - Mar 14') but overlay the income calculation ('21 available nights = $X potential income'). (2) At listing creation: When the host enters their schedule, immediately show the income potential of that schedule. Don't wait for pricing to show value. (3) At proposal matching: Frame incoming proposals against the host's schedule: 'Guest request: Feb 22 - Mar 10 (17 of your 21 available nights). Potential income: $X.' (4) Use the host's own anchor ($5,500/mo rent) as the reference point: 'This month's bookings cover 85% of your rent.'

evidence.quote: I go away for three weeks. I come back for two weeks, so it's a weird schedule. It's expensive, you know, my part's expensive to make some money on this.
evidence.insight: Kris frames his schedule as weird and his apartment as expensive. The platform must reframe: 'Your 3-week availability is highly desirable for our guests' and 'Your premium property commands $X/night.'

evidence.quote: Small and apparently insignificant details can have major impacts on people's behavior. A good rule of thumb is to assume that everything matters.
evidence.insight: How the schedule is displayed IS the nudge. 'Away 3 weeks' vs '21 bookable nights' is the same information with completely different motivational impact.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: Income potential calculation tied to schedule. Secondary: Schedule visualization (calendar). Tertiary: Schedule flexibility options.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Immediately upon schedule entry: Show income calculation. On calendar view: Overlay available vs occupied nights with income summation. On proposal receipt: Frame proposal against schedule and income target.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: One number dominates: monthly income potential. Support with exactly 2 sub-numbers: available nights count and nightly rate. Do not show more than 3 numbers in the schedule-value display.
exclude: Guest demand forecasting beyond one month ahead
